STRINGS: "--Come out.
I'd like to ask you some questions."
At my simple instructions,
Soujirou Sekimoto obeyed without complaint.
"You're late.
I was getting kind of tired of waiting."
I didn't have the luxury of worrying about
every single delberately evasive comment he made.
I stared at him for a while.
Sekimoto, however, doesn't seem interested in that.
"Can't you just tell me the important matters quickly?"
"There was a new victim just now."
"Okay, continue."
"The M.O. was really distinctive
--both eyes were severely damaged.
...As if they were pierced with scissors."
"I see. Anything else?"
"There was also a note.
It said, "Give me your eyes".
I want to hear your opinion."
I took a deep breath,
making up my mind at the same time as
fresh air filled my lungs.
I prepared myself to learn whatever I could
from this criminal case defendant.
"--Tell me about Blindman,
I want to know everything there is to know."
"It's finally my turn, huh? All right.
Better sit down, because this story is a long one."
"But with this, you'll understand that my theory was right."
Sekimoto grinned as he said that.
"Blindman is an urban legend, no doubt,
but it's netlore to be exact.
Hojou, do you know what netlore is?"
"If I remember correctly,
they're urban legends that originated on the Internet--"
"Correct. When the method of transmission is
by word of mouth, they're called folklore."
"In contrast, the spread of rumors through online bulletin boards,
e-mail, and social networking sites is called netlore.
However, this definition hasn't been fully accepted academically."
Sekimoto's tone of voice had completely changed from before.
He sounded sagacious and succint.
His powerful eloquence would leave
listeners with no room for doubt.
"But where Net Lore differs significantly from
its predecessors is in the relative ease with
which it can track the changes and evolution of a story."
"For example, "Blindman" can be looked up on a search engine,
then have the results sorted by date to see how the
content has transformed over time in a matter of seconds."
"It's a very convenient world we live in, isn't it?"
"Do you know the original version of this Blindman urban legend?"
"Well. The starting point is nothing much.
It's a blog post about a man living alone who
lost his eyesight and is struggling to get his vision back."
"He incessantly appealed to others to register on the eye bank.
Probably because the greater the number of registrants,
the sooner he would get his cornea transplant."
"At the same time, he would introduce people to agencies that
dealt with such matters in each part of the country.
He'd respond to comments to increase registrations even a little."
"It was then that a turning point in his destiny came.
Do you know why?"
"No... What do you mean?"
"He suffered a so-called flame war.
People began to doubt the man's truthfulness."
"I don't really see why they'd do that..."
"Are you sure about that?
Then how could he reply to comments on his blog?"
Ah... I see, I see.
Strictly speaking, he probably used the read-out function to reply.
But I guess the masses didn't realize that.
"So, what happened to the man?"
"They abandoned the blog and just disappeared.
But that was the trigger to a whole new set of rumors."
"The blogger who vanished said that he was
looking for the person who instigated the flame war.
"Once he finds them, he's gonna take revenge, won't he?"."
"Such speculation led to rumors,
and this distorted image of him was set in stone.
The rumors transformed him into a "monster that crush both eyes"."
"That's how Blindman... came to be?"
"On the surface, yes. But only ostensibly."
"Even a proper rumor can easily take a life of its own,
as long as it has credibility."
"Listen. What people are searching for is not the truth.
They want a story that is plausible and that they can relate to.
That's what that blind man's story is now."
"Pure feelings and actions.
Heartless slander and libel, their result, tragedy.
That alone is enough to send rumors spiraling out of control."
He's the very definition of serious.
But the content of his talk is so conceptual
that, to be honest, I can barely keep up.
"So you're saying... that the story
you just told is a fabrication?
What's the truth then?"
"It's an experiment. This was just an experiment."
"Eh? What do you mean?
I don't see what you're getting at in the least."
"Calm down.
Simply put-"
"This story was created for the purposes of
my research, and I let it circulate."
...What?
What did he just say?
"I'm the creator of the urban legend "Blindman"."
Sekimoto declared.
That fact had enough impact to halt my train of thought.
"In other words, you made up Blindman?"
"That's right."
"Then why does the Blindman exists in reality!?"
"That is unknown, even to me.
But I am responsible for this case.
That's why I spoke up at the trial."
"Please. Tell me everything step by step.
Just the facts. Concisely.
Let me get the story straight."
"Alright.
It's still going to be a long story."
Sekimoto sighed deeply.
Then he slowly closed his eyelids and relaxed.
"The origin of the urban legend "Blindman" was
a project that started as an experiment
regarding folklore, which I major in."
"The objective was to determine how quickly
certain information spreads through word-of-mouth means,
such as from person to person, over the Internet, and so on."
"We would also examine how the contents
were transformed in the process."
"The data obtained would have provided the basis for more
efficient viral marketing, commonly used by advertisement agencies,
and the faster resolution of hoax-induced mayhem."
"So what I prepared were the vestiges of
a blind man's campaign and the subsequent uproar--"
"And finally, the monster called "Blindman".
The character was fleshed out to rival
existing urban legends such as Hikiko-san and Kunekune."
"And so, "Blindman" rapidly grew its
presence through the Internet, right?"
"No... the spread in the beginning was so slow
you could say it was nothing at all.
I had even sock-puppetted on high-traffic imageboards."
"And yet, if I'm to be honest, almost no one was interested.
I hated myself for my inadequacies back then."
"However, one day, after dispassionately repeating this charade,
my miserable feelings likely a way to cope with my failure,
it suddenly started to disseminate."
"I believe that I probably reached the minimum amount of
broadcasting necesary for a rumor to spread.
If I could, I would've published a paper on this hypothesis."
"And so, the very contents of the story of "Blindman" were
gradually being altered by the users that retold it themselves."
"Ifelt joy as if my own child was growing
before my very eyes, but at the same time,
there was this loneliness at its independence."
"Hold on for a second.
Sorry, but I still don't understand what you're getting at."
My head was on the verge of overheating
at the overwhelming amount of information
it was being fed all at once.
I pinched the tip of my nose to clear my mind.
"This can't be everything... right?
At this point, I'm not even sure how to connect
you to any of the incidents that have occurred so far."
"Students need a patient mind.
On the path to the truth, no shortcut exists.
...That being said, you're the detective here."
Let's rewind a bit.
As you wish, from chronological order, he said,
then Sekimoto began speaking again.
"When the progress of project I had lost all hope on suddenly
had a sharp recovery, my students and I were very relieved."
"However, one of the students stopped coming all together.
At first, I thought nothing of it as these caprices happened often.
His assignment was trivial, after all."
"At that same time, Blindman had taken off and I was very busy,
which is why I was one week too late when
I noticed the gravity of the situation."
"If I'm honest, I had become absorbed in the experiment.
After all, sightings of Blindman started to appear.
Some people from the Internet even called the police."
"But it didn't end there.
An actual victim surfaced in reality.
Tamura the banker, and then there's tonight's newest victim.
This is our current situation."
"Moreover, the circumstances of the murders are
eerily similar to the earliest versions I tried circulating.
Only a limited number of people were able to read them."
"Who were those limited number of people?
Be more specific."
"The students that filled my seminar room.
They had a chance to observe the contents during
the draft stage of the experiment."
"Isn't it possible that it's just a coincidence?
For example, that the M.O. just so happens to be similar?"
"...About the victim discovered earlier,
was there a message from Blindman in her mouth?"
It said [Give me your eyes]."
As soon as I told him what we found,
his expression began to cloud over.
"In the drafts, I made it so that a message meant for
the first to find the body was placed in the victim's mouth."
That means..."
"That's right.
You are Blindman's next target."
"There's no way...!
But, that's just something you made up, right?"
"Listen to me, Hojou.
This person knows what Blindman is...
And is copying his M.O."
"You could say that a ficticious existence
only meant to exist on paper has become real."
This is no longer a matter of his creation or anything like that...
I'm now the target of a monster that commits strange murders by
piercing both of the victim's eyes with a pair of scissors.
I'll be killed.
By having both my eyes pierced.
"...And that's my story.
But I have more to tell.
You're interested in knowing why I nominated you, correct?"
"It's because you read about me in a magazine--"
"Did you really believe that?
You're so easily fooled by lies at times."
"Then, what's the truth...?"
"I've looked into you.
You've had the dead follow you your whole life.
My heart suddenly began to beat faster.
How does he know that?
"Why did you become a detective here?"
"And do you think you're cleverly hiding it?"
I'm speechless.
It's like I'm staring down a snake, and I am its next meal.
"I'm not like you.
Yes, I have faced many hardships and unfortunate events.
But I'm no criminal."
"I know all about that.
Like I said, I've looked into your past."
"It all started from one trivial thought.
I was curious about the probability of coming across a
scene of death during one's lifetime. That's when I found you."
"As I carefully studied past news reports--
especially murders and serious accidents--
I noticed that you're always looming
in the shadows of these incidents."
"But, why is that?
By all means, explain yourself.
As compensation for this extracurricular lecture."
"Please don't do this."
"This incident may have been caused by your fate as well."
"Please stop...!"
"You're like Belial.
Do you know who that is?
That's the name of the devil, and a fallen angel."
"He appears as an angel of beautiful form,
but lies as easily as he breathes.
They say it takes a sacrifice to get Belial to tell the truth."
"Please cut it out!!"
"What's going on!?
D-did something happen???"
"Huff... Huff... Huff... Huff...!"
My heart's still racing.
I looked into Kazamori's eyes, spontaneously begging for help.
He seemed to have sensed something.
"Sekimoto... what did you just do?"
"Why, nothing at all.
I was telling her the information I had."
"Hojou, is this true?"
I'm having trouble elocuting myself.
My body refuses to obey my commands.
"Sekimoto... Stop with the bullshit.
What did you do to my partner, huh!?"
"Nothing, all I did was ask a few questions.
More importantly, go search for
"Uh, what was that?
Take something?"
"Shin'ichirou Takenaka.
He was a researcher enrolled in my class,
as well as a resident of Town C."
"What the hell does that have to do with anything?"
"You can ask Ms. Hojou for more details.
I told her everything I knew.
Mr. Takenaka was the student who vanished from right under my nose."
"Oy, you're talking complete nonsense...!"
"Kazamori... Let's go.
To this Shin'ichirou Takenaka's residence."
"Hojou...!?"
I stood up and caught my breath.
Truth be told, I have yet to stop my trembling.
However, it's not hard to imagine Kazamori getting into
an argument with Sekimoto that would have made things worse
if I hadn't put up a bold front then.
"But... don't push yourself too hard, okay?"
"I was finally able to get him to talk properly.
We can't let this chance slip through our fingers."
"Y-yeah, sure... You did good, Hojou."
"Let's go, Kazamori!"
I returned Sekimoto to his cell
and flew out of the detention center with initiative.
Kazamori followed close behind.
However, just moving my body helped relieve
the weight I had felt all over my body just a while ago.
Little by little, I felt the intrusive thoughts vanish,
but even so, the lump of discomfort in my heart remained.
--That man is toying with me.
